Award.AwardTitle: EDU: Flipping the Online Security Classroom - Improving Retention of Security Student Pipeline through Early Intervention

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is applying the concept of a 'flipped classroom' to cyber security education using blended learning and online environments. Students participating in this program work on virtual laboratory exercises collaboratively under instructor supervision through various modalities, including individual video chats, group video chats (e.g. Google Hangout), and simulated virtual environments (e.g. Second Life). The project is also using cloud technology to create a remotely accessible cyber security and forensics laboratory environment that provides tools for students across multiple community colleges and the University at Albany, SUNY. The project is also employing a train-the-trainer program that allows instructors to share expertise and jointly develop laboratory exercises. These activities are amortizing curriculum development costs allowing multiple institutions to sustain and support a successful cyber security and digital forensics program. There is a shortage of talent to meet the economic and national security threats posed by cyber attacks, which is expected to worsen as potential students migrate away from information technology fields. This project is improving accessibility to state-of-the-art tools to institutions that would otherwise lack the resources to obtain them; at the same time, it is enriching cyber security and forensics education in community colleges while creating a better pipeline to four-year colleges. Successful development of cloud computing laboratories for this purpose is resulting in best practices and lessons learned for other disciplines and institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An Online Flipped Classroom: Improving Providing Access to High Quality Security Education

Sanjay Goel and Kevin Williams

University at Albany, SUNY

Our goal of the project was to test the concept of online flipped classroom for security education and to facilitate such an online learning environment, create a virtual environment to provide access to sophisticated security and forensics software to students.  While flipped classrooms have become popular, they require classroom access for students.  Especially in cyber security education, flipped classrooms are very useful, especially since theoretical concepts need to be anchored in real context through hands-on learning for creating a job-ready workforce.  We developed a virtualized environment where sophisticated security and forensics tools can be made accessible to the students online such that they can read materials ahead of class and work with instructors on problems and assignments through online forums simulating a flipped classroom online. The advantage of such virtualization is that students get the same access to resources when they are in a physical classroom, virtual classroom, or when working at home on their homework and assignments that require the software tools that they use in class. We have tested our infrastructure with virtualization solutions from different vendors and have created a 30-seat virtual environment.  We examined the learning outcomes and student satisfaction across a regular classroom, traditional flipped classroom, and a virtual flipped classroom.

Our goal was to ensure a comparable pedagogic experience for the students in a virtual flipped classroom as in a face-to-face flipped classroom. We compared the traditional classroom, flipped classroom and online flipped classroom through a series of experiment: 1) Virtual Flipped vs. Conventional Flipped – controlling for instructor and content; 2) Traditional Classroom (Lecture) vs. Conventional Flipped vs. Virtual Flipped – controlling for instructor and content; 3) Conventional Flipped vs. Virtual Flipped – different instructors, same course. The results of the classroom studies were mixed. The most positive results for the virtual flipped format occurred in an upper level course taught by an instructor who was experienced in flipped classroom formats. In his two classes, the virtual format was received more favorably in one, and was equivalent to the conventional flipped format in the other. However, in the studies conducted with lower-level courses and instructors less experienced with the flipped format, students did not respond as favorably to the virtual format. Study 3 suggested that instructor and technology effects are likely to affect the success of the virtual format. Some instructors may be more comfortable and competent using the flipped format and/or the technology employed by the virtual format. Additional training may be necessary for instructors using the virtual format. The finding in Study 2 that students reacted more favorably to a traditional lecture-based format than either flipped format is surprising, given previous evidence on flipped classrooms. The instructor may not have been effective using in the flipped format, or perhaps the course content did not lend itself to the flipped format.  Alternatively, perhaps the students in lower level courses in the major are more comfortable with lecture-based classroom instruction. Overall, the findings suggest that the virtual flipped format performs on par with the conventional flipped format. The success of either approach will depend strongly on training provided to instructors and the extent to which they embrace the format. The virtual format has additional concerns related to the technology it requires; as the technique is used more, the technology should become more reliable.

Our goal is also to provide the same infrastructure to community college students as students get to improve the training of transfer students transitioning to the 4-year program at UAlbany (or another school). By working with similar tools and being familiar with the environment used in the classroom at UAlbany transfer students feel more confident and as such their readiness is improved. We have articulation agreements with five community colleges and have tested this concept with two of them. We will work with our community college partners to adopt our infrastructure in their regular curriculum and evaluate how student success for transfer students is improving.

The infrastructure is now embedded in the Digital Forensics curriculum at the University at Albany and the blueprint of our infrastructure is now being adopted by the university’s Information Technology Services to roll such facilities out to other programs at the University. We will work on expanding this infrastructure such that we create a digital backpack for all the students where they have the software loaded corresponding to the classes that they are enrolled in. We are also working on models that will recover the cost of the software by bundling the software license fees for students into their curricular material.
